header.title: The Scroll of Set - August 1994
header.category: Western Esotericism, Modern Occultism, Setian Philosophy, Practical Magic

central_thesis: This collection of articles from The Scroll of Set outlines diverse approaches to Setian initiation and self-transformation (Xeper), emphasizing the dynamic evolution and purification of core concepts, the importance of individual magical practice, critical self-evaluation, and active projection of the Initiate's will into the objective universe.

structure_content.summary: This article discusses 'Xem' as a concept within the Temple of Set, asserting its 'death' as a natural evolution and its 'remanifestation' as a purified form through an alchemical process, highlighting the dynamic and evolving nature of Setian thought and 'Words'.

This piece details the establishment of 'Woodharrow' as a physical manifestation of V° work, specifically the 'Utterance of a Word' called Runa. Runa is defined as an encapsulated, actively projected philosophical seed-form designed to have tangible, permanent effects on the objective universe, supported by a 'Runakona' (Scarlet Woman), and serving as a center for ritual workings and studies.

This article provides guidelines for ethical and intellectual conduct within the Temple of Set, stressing the importance of supporting Xeper, respecting diverse Setian types, skeptical honesty, avoiding politics and rumors, and open-minded analysis of advanced Initiate statements to foster genuine growth.

This article proposes a practical magical system to become the 'causative agent' of one's own initiation and existence across time. It involves using the 'Nine Angles' framework to perform a series of workings, starting from conception, to retroactively influence past events, giving the 'Dark Gift' to one's past self, and thus ritualizing self-recognition as Set.

Elaborating on 'Xem is Dead,' this article introduces the concept of 'sacred cows' ('xow') as parasitic distortions covering valid 'Words.' It advocates for 'alchemical dialectic' or 'digestive transformation' to break down, rearrange, and reassemble concepts, purifying them to experience the 'Form before the Word,' exemplified by Xem and Runa.

This article offers practical advice for new Setians, emphasizing the importance of extensive reading, seeking guidance from the Priesthood, asking questions, persevering through self-doubt, engaging in practical ritual work, and meticulously keeping a journal to track initiatory progress.

This article outlines essential practices for continuous self-evolution, including 'The Death of Former Selves' (discarding past states), rites of passage for transcendence, objective journaling for perceiving change, differentiating 'I' from 'Not I' (annihilating counter-productive aspects), and recognizing 'social dead-ends.' It also presents a 'time travel' technique for re-evaluating the past.

structure_content.chapter_title: [17] The Red Magus and the Priesthood of Set
structure_content.summary: This article defines a 'Red Magus' as a powerful being guiding others towards being, operating with a scope beyond human priests. It describes the Initiate's path to this state and the Priesthood's function as a means of survival, acting with reason for self-benefit and, indirectly, the advancement of humanity.

key_concepts.definition: The core Setian principle of self-creation and becoming, representing the goal of initiation and requiring continuous self-evaluation and transformation.
A 'Word' or concept within the Eon of Set, subject to 'death' and 'Remanifestation' through alchemical processes, signifying the dynamic evolution and purification of ideas within Setian philosophy.
The process of bringing forth a new, purified, and improved form of an existing concept or self, often following an 'alchemical' transformation or a symbolic 'death' of the old form.

A methodology for purifying 'Words' or concepts from their 'xow' (sacred cows) by breaking down existing systems (physical, magical, psychic), rearranging them, and reassembling them into new, more advanced entities. It emphasizes experiencing the 'Form before the Word'.
Parasitic viruses or distortions that attach to and obscure valid 'Words' or sacred elements, preventing true understanding and initiation; they must be identified and transformed.

A V° work concept where an encapsulated seed-form of a philosophy (e.g., Runa) is actively projected 'outward' into the objective universe to generate tangible, real, and permanent effects, serving as a direct manifestation of the Magus's will.
An individual, such as Crystal Dawn, who acts as the external manifestation of a Magus's 'Word' (e.g., Runa) and is deemed indispensable in the practical, objective manifestation of that work.

A practical magical system designed to enable the Initiate to become the 'causative agent' of their own past experiences and initiation, ritualizing self-recognition as Set by 'giving the Dark Gift' to their past self across the boundaries of time, using the 'Nine Angles' framework.

A crucial aspect of Setian initiation involving the conscious and unconscious discarding or transformation of past states of being to facilitate the development and advancement of the higher self, often formalized at Recognition to a higher degree.

A being capable of initiating others into being, operating with a greater scope than human priests, working with reason and self-interest as a means of survival, and indirectly contributing to the benefit of humanity through their work.

A physical estate serving as a platform for the 'Utterance of the Word Runa' into the objective universe, dedicated to ritual workings, seminars, and workshops in Runelore, Hermetic/Typhonian, and Celtic studies.

practical_system.description: The text outlines several interconnected practical systems and methodologies for Setian initiation and self-transformation (Xeper). These include the 'Retroactive Enchantment' for temporal magical influence and self-creation, the 'Alchemical Dialectic' for purifying and evolving 'Words' or concepts, rigorous 'Re-evaluation of the Self' through conscious 'death of former selves' and objective journaling, and the 'Utterance of a Word' (Runa) for projecting philosophical seed-forms into objective reality. Emphasis is placed on direct action, personal responsibility, continuous self-assessment, and interaction with the Temple structure for guidance and support.
tools: Journal/Diary: For objective recording of initiatory development, self-analysis, and review of past workings and experiences.
Ritual Chamber: A dedicated physical space for personal magical workings, or an area evoking strong personal memories for 'time travel' workings.
Common Ritual Supplies & Objects: Music, photographs, smells, and other items that serve a nostalgic purpose or aid in focus for specific workings.
Nine Angles Framework: A conceptual structure used for organizing temporal magical workings within the Retroactive Enchantment system.
Words/Concepts (e.g., Xem, Runa): Philosophical constructs or archetypes used as foci for alchemical transformation, projection, and self-definition.
Priesthood & Other Initiates: A network for correspondence, guidance, feedback, and collaboration on projects or 'working partners'.
rituals: Retroactive Enchantment: Perform a series of workings using the 'Nine Angles' framework, starting from one's earliest life event (conception), to retroactively will past events into being, guiding past selves into the 'World of Horrors' to take responsibility for existence and give the 'Dark Gift'.

Alchemical Dialectic/Digestive Transformation: Break down existing systems or concepts ('sacred cows'), rearrange them, and reassemble into new, improved entities to experience the 'Form before the Word' (purifying the essence of a concept).

Death of Former Selves/Rites of Passage: Consciously undergo 'deaths' of past self-states, using focus and refinement to transcend into new realms of being, including introducing 'counter-productive former selves' to the 'Black Flame for annihilation' or transformation.

'Time Travel'/Bringing the Past to the Present: Utilize nostalgia and ritual to bring past events into the ritual chamber for review, analysis, and refinement, thereby actively shaping the present self.

Objective Self-Analysis: Maintain a careful, objective diary or journal of initiatory development to analyze changes in personal growth, differentiate subjective interpretations from objective reality, and understand the self.

Utterance of a Word: Actively project an encapsulated philosophical seed-form (e.g., Runa) into the objective universe to manifest tangible effects, such as the establishment of a dedicated physical space for ritual workings and studies (e.g., Woodharrow).

relevant_quotes.text: Xem is Dead. Long live Xem.
The Pylon aims to encourage each member to evaluate what it is to be Setian, how one becomes Setian, and then to apply this knowledge while undergoing the process of initiation.

The eternal substance of V° work is the Utterance of a Word. Such a Word is the encapsulated seed-form of an all-encompassing philosophy. Into the seed-form the whole can be compressed, and from it can the whole be derived. Its "Utterance” is the actual work itself - the active projection of that Word “outward” into the objective universe, where it is to have tangible, real, permanent effects. The Word is furthermore a real embodiment of the highest essence of the Magus who Utters it.
What if I am to take the archetype of Set and apply it to myself in such a way that I am he who gives myself the Dark Gift - across the boundaries of time?

By willing past events into being, I make sure they happen, take the element of randomness out of my subjective mythos, and become as Set - giving the Gift to myself in a previous time. My self to my self I shall give.

Sacred cows, like stuffed animals, cannot really be killed, because they were never alive to begin with. Rather they are like parasitic viruses that are only able to replicate and amplify themselves through living, breathing hosts. Such has been the case with Xem, a valid (read: living) Word within the Eon of Set whose history has shown it to bring out the best and worst among those Setians who have used it in their initiation.

I have termed this process, “the alchemical dialectic”, but it is digestive transformation by any name - the principle represented by the Jackal, exemplified by the Anubis neter, and enacted by the Magus of Xem in his utterance of the Word. Indeed it is the method intrinsic to Xem itself.

The constant re-evaluation of the self is a vital procedure for the Setian. Initiation is arrested when this process is forgotten or ignored, and it is considerably more difficult to regain a former level of personal evolution when an attained level is not refined through vigorous analysis.

It is the responsibility of the Initiate to utilize death as a rite of passage, employing the tools of focus and refinement to bring about the passage. This process can also be conceptualized as a form of Remanifestation...

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection of articles is highly relevant for understanding the internal dynamics, philosophical evolution, and practical magical applications within the Temple of Set during the mid-1990s. It showcases diverse approaches to Xeper, encompassing philosophical concepts (Xem, Runa), practical self-transformation techniques (Retroactive Enchantment, Avoiding Dead-Ends), ethical guidelines for initiates, and institutional updates. It provides a valuable snapshot of the intellectual and practical concerns of prominent Setian initiates and leaders, with specific articles (e.g., Aquino's refutation) offering crucial historical context regarding challenges faced by the Temple of Set.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of active members of the Temple of Set across all degrees (Initiates, Priesthood, Pylon Sentinels), individuals deeply interested in Setian philosophy and practices, researchers of modern occultism and Left-Hand Path traditions, and those exploring personal self-transformation through structured magical systems. Specific content, such as 'Letter to the New Initiate' and 'Gates of Hell Pylon Update,' caters to newer or geographically distant members, while articles like 'Vox Runica Corvorum' and 'On Being and Bovines' address more advanced philosophical and practical themes pertinent to experienced Initiates.
